question: What is the cause of acute respiratory distress syndrome in adults?

A 35-year-old alcoholic woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of shortness of breath and cough with green-colored and blood-stained sputum. On examination, a cold sore was found and a bronchial breath sound at the right lung base was heard. On X-ray, right lower lobe haziness is seen. What is the organism responsible for her symptoms?
A man was hospitalized due to an episode of cardiac arrest. After 72 hours of stay, he developed new symptoms; cough, chest pain, and fever. What is the most probable cause?

A 40-year-old female with a known case of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) presents to the outpatient department with complaints of productive cough with sputum, fever with chills, and wheezing. Which of the following types of pneumonia is responsible for this?
Which type of emphysema is most common in smoking?
Dust cells are produced by which of the following?
Which of these diseases is characterized by fever, cough, and patchy infiltrates on the lung?
Which of these conditions is characterized by hyperinflation of the lungs?

A 26-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with complaints of wheezing, shortness of breath, and a barrel-shaped chest. History suggested a 10-year pack history. On X-ray, hyperinflated lungs are seen. Which is the most probable diagnosis?

A young man presents to the nearby clinic with complaints of shortness of breath and cough with a copious amount of mucus production. He is found infertile and is diagnosed with immotile cilia syndrome. What is defective in this syndrome?

A 40-year-old alcoholic lady presents to the outpatient department with complaints of shortness of breath and cough with yellow-green sputum. Her chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation. Which type of pneumonia is present?
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in adults is a deficiency of which of the following?
Pigeon-shaped chest is associated with which disease?
Which of these is the most common finding in asthma?
Which of these organisms causes atypical pneumonia?
What is the first product formed in the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes?
What is a common cause of ischemic hypoxia?
Which of these is a common upper respiratory tract infection?
If a Gohn focus is located in the apices of the lung, this signifies which of the following conditions?
Which of these forms of tuberculosis can not be transmitted?
If a diabetic person is having ketonuria, this suggests an underlying?
What is the most common benign tumor of the lungs?
Which microorganism commonly causes pneumonia in alcoholics?
An HIV-infected woman presents to the outpatient department with fever, chills, and cough with sputum. Which of the following infections does she have?
Which of the following carcinogens present in cigarettes accelerates heart rate and the activity of the nervous system?

A 50-year-old female has experienced a 5 kg weightloss over the last 3 months. She recently developed low grade fever and cough with mucoid sputum production and after 2 weeks, she experienced blood streaked sputum. There are bilateral crackles in the left upper lobe on auscultation of the chest. The sputum smear shows bright red bacilli against a bluish background. Which of the following findings are most likely to be present in the sputum sample?

A 12-year-old girl has a 7 year history of coughing, wheezing, and repeated attacks of difficulty in breathing. The attacks get more common during spring. During an episode of acute respiratory difficulty, physical examination shows that she is afebrile. Her lungs are hyper-resonant on percussion and chest radiograph shows increased lucency of all lung fields. Laboratory tests show an elevated serum IgE level and peripheral blood eosinophilia. Sputum sample is examined and it also has increased number of eosinophils. Which of the following histological features are most likely a characteristic feature of this condition?

answers.option: Alveolar and interstitial edema with sheets of macrophages
Dilatation of bronchi and loss of elastic tissue
Remodeling of airways with smooth muscle hyperplasia

question: Which of the following types of cancer involves the chromosome 3p deletions and mutations in TP53, Rb?
Which of the following progresses from interstitial fibrosis, diffuse fibrosis to characteristic end-stage honeycomb appearance?
Which of the following terms is used to describe a bluish-purple discoloration of the mucosa and the skin due to reduced hemoglobin content in the body?
Which of the following terms is used to indicate the benign neoplasm of glandular epithelial cells?
What is the cause of atypical pneumonia?

A female patient was brought to the emergency department with chest pain. She was a known case of mediastinal lymphoma. Doppler's ultrasound revealed the presence of the milky fluid in the pleural cavity which points towards the obstruction of the thoracic duct by the tumor mass. Which of the following entities designates this condition?
Which of the following organisms is most likely to cause pneumonia in an immunocompromised patient?
What is the cause of community-acquired pneumonia?
Exposure to which of the following is most likely to cause mesothelioma?
Which of the following is the most common cause of lung cancer?
What does a positive Mantoux skin test indicate?

A 16-year-old male came to the emergency department with shortness of breath and drowsiness. He was in respiratory distress. On the chest x-ray, there was atelectasis of the lungs due to air accumulation. There was no history of trauma or perforating injury. This clinical picture is mostly seen in which of the following conditions?
Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. What is the fundamental abnormality in asthma?

answers.option: Exaggerated Th-2 response to environmental allergens
Exaggerated Th-1 response to environmental allergens

question: A female patient came to the outpatient department with chest pain. Her X-ray reports showed the hard mass in her right chest . Upon bronchoscopy, it was confirmed to be lung cancer. Which of the following is the most common site for tracheobronchial cancers to occur?
Which of the following is not true about rhinitis?
What is a chronic inflammatory condition of the lung airways resulting in episodic airflow obstruction called?

A 60-year-old man has had fever, night sweats, and a 7 kg weight loss over the past 4 months. In the past month, he has had episodes of hemoptysis. He dies of respiratory failure and hypoxemia. Infection with which of the following organisms is most likely to have produced these findings?

A 70-year-old male came to the outpatient department with shortness of breath and productive cough of yellow sputum. He also had a clinical history of high-grade fever for 5 days. On the chest x-ray, there was fluid inside the pleural cavity. Which of the following is the most probable etiology of fluid in this patient?
No single test can secure a diagnosis of asthma. Which of the following is the most helpful and preferred method for establishing the diagnosis?
Which of the following protein concentrations indicates that the fluid collected in the pleural cavity is an exudative fluid when serum protein content is normal?

A 55-year-old male was admitted to the hospital with complaints of shortness of breath for a day, he had a history of hip replacement surgery and he was immobile. He was a suspected case of pulmonary embolism. Which is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism?

A patient came to the emergency department. His pulse and blood pressure were undetectable. While his history was being taken, the doctor came to know that the patient had severe hypertension. An immediate X-ray was ordered and it showed fluid in the pleural cavity following an aortic aneurysm and pleuritis. What condition would the patient most likely be suffering from?

A 42-year-old male patient comes to the emergency with complaints of fever with chills and cough for one week with a large amount of sputum and pain in the chest. Community-acquired pneumonia is suspected. What is the most common cause in such a case?

A 32-year-old lady presents with a 2-day history of shortness of breath, fever, and cough. On examination, she is tachypneic, dyspneic, and shows low blood oxygen saturation. There are no signs of cardiac failure. Chest x-ray shows bilateral lung infiltrates. Which of the following best describes the lung morphology on microscopy?

answers.option: Large, dilated alveoli with bullae formation
Eosinophils and mast cells in abundance

question: A 25-year-old male was admitted to the ward with complaints of shortness of breath for a day. He had a history of long hours travel. There is a positive family history of thrombosis in his first-degree relative. On investigation, a chest x-ray shows Westermark's sign and Hampton's hump signs. Which is the most probable diagnosis of these findings?
Community-acquired pneumonia is mostly caused by specific bacteria. The most common organism can be diagnosed in the lab by which of the following test?
A patient with which disease has a high risk of acquiring tuberculosis?
What is the common pathology in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)?
If a patient suffering from pneumonia has a dry, gray lung, then he is going through which phase of pneumonia?

A 46-year-old woman goes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. On physical examination, there are no remarkable findings. Her body mass index is 22. She does not smoke. A tuberculin skin test is positive. A chest radiograph shows a solitary, 3-cm left upper lobe mass. The mass is removed during thoracotomy by wedge resection. The microscopic appearance of this lesion shows granulomas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following represents the mechanism of action of the nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs?

answers.option: It helps in metabolizing arachidonic acid
It helps in the formation of prostaglandins
It helps in the formation of steroids

question: Which of the following molecular substances plays an important role in the adhesion-rolling phase of the leukocytes recruitment?
Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Which of the following are risk factors for the development of asthma?

Chronic bronchitis is characterized by the destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue leading to permanent dilatation of airways. Which of the following are the major morphological changes seen in chronic bronchitis?

answers.option: Increased mucosal gland depth compared to the thickness of the wall between the epithelium and the cartilage
Reid index of 0.4 is normal and is observed in chronic bronchitis
Slight increase in goblet cell number but markedly so in small airways

question: Asthma is characterized by chest tightness, wheezing, sputum production, cough, and airway hyperresponsiveness. Which one of the following is the most characteristic factor of bronchial asthma?

answers.option: Symptoms are the same for every person with asthma

question: A child developed a common cold during his trip to northern areas and his parents are worried because the child has been a patient of asthma, but after taking complete medications it was cured. They read it somewhere that there are some structural changes that occur in the airway of asthmatic patients. What are the structural changes that develop in patients with asthma and how do they increase the risk of asthma recurrence?

answers.option: Smooth muscle hypertrophy which increase chances of reversible bronchoconstriction
Alveolar walls degenerate causing less gaseous exchange
Alveolar capillaries are constricted that collapse of bronchioles
Increased sensitivity followed by fainting and blue lips

question: Which of the following is the most common age for the development of atopic asthma?
Which of the following is related to persistent asthma?
In tuberculosis, the Gohn complex is formed when the lesion of the lungs travels where?
A student has final exams due to which his breathing has increased. What condition can he develop?
Which of the following can lead to asthma in an adult?
Mesothelioma is associated with exposure to which of the following?
Asthma is commonly characterized as which of the following type of disease on the basis of etiology?
Which of the following interleukins is involved in eosinophil chemotaxis?
A 40-year-old man presents with high-grade fever (102°F), productive cough, and chest pain. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
Which of the following is a common symptom for cor pulmonale?
A young girl develops rhinitis and nasal polyps. Which of the following does not correspond to this condition?
A person suffers an injury in the lower limb. After 2 weeks, he came to the hospital with complaints of dyspnea. On the chest x-ray, a wedge-shaped infarct is seen. What is most likely the diagnosis?

A patient had tuberculosis and was advised anti-tuberculosis therapy but stopped after 7 days on the advice of the physician. He had developed pleuritis as tuberculosis has extended into the cavity. What other conditions can cause pleuritis?
A patient presents to the emergency department with an acid smell or acetone breath. Which of the following is the person suffering from?
Which of the following is the most common cause of the chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)?
Which of the following structures is compressed by the Hiatal hernia?
What is the most common lung tumor?
A man who works as a laborer in the ship-breaking industry comes to the outpatient department with pleural plaque bilaterally in both lungs and malignant mesothelioma. What is the causative agent?
In congestive heart failure, the lungs and sputum contain heart failure cells. What are those cells?
Caseating granulomas are found in tuberculosis. This is an example of which type of hypersensitivity?

A boy who is under post-operative care after knee surgery is administered morphine 4 grams intravenously after every two hours. His respiratory rate is 8 and he is extremely drowsy. Which condition is he most likely to have?
A 60-year-old lady comes into the clinic with complaints of off-and-on symptoms of asthma. She is a known case of chronic asthma. What is the reason for her recurring symptoms?
What is the commonest cause of ischemic hypoxia?

answers.option: Decreased blood flow to tissues with normal Hb and pO2

question: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest tightness, breathlessness, cough, and a feeling of suffocation. What is most likely to occur in this condition?

A young man presented to the clinic with shortness of breath and a cough with copious mucus production. He is found to be infertile and has a condition called immotile cilia syndrome. Which part has the primary defect in this syndrome?
Which of the following is the most common predisposing factor for asthma in adults?

A 44-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to the sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain that started a few hours ago. Last week he had an accident and he has been immobilized since then due to left leg pain and calf swelling. The patient has no other medical condition, no addiction, and is not on any medication. His body temperature is 36 °C. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and his respiratory rate is 28 breaths per minute. His chest X-ray revealed a wedge-shaped infarct. What could be the underlying cause?
What is the most common cause of pleural mesothelioma and lung cancer?
A person admitted to the hospital is in a coma. Analysis of arterial blood gave the following values: PCO2 25mm Hg, HCO3- 5mmol/l, and pH 7.1. What is the underlying acid-base disorder?
The definition of obstructive pattern in pulmonary function tests is best defined by which of the following?

answers.option: FVC that is less than 95% of predicted
Total lung capacity that is more than 70 to 75% of predicted
Total lung capacity that is less than 70 to 75% of predicted
FEV1/FVC that is less than 70-75% of the predicted
Maximal mid expiratory flow is less than 75% of predicted

question: A 35-year-old factory worker comes to the outpatient department with complaints of fever, chills, and pain in the right side of his chest. He has worked in a factory for 8 years. His blood count shows raised white blood cells, normal hemoglobin, and raised ESR. What is the etiology of this condition?

A 47-year-old lady with diabetes comes to the hospital with complaints of fever and chills. The fever is associated with vomiting and cough. She explains she had the flu a week ago. Her total white blood cell count is raised and her culture shows the growth of Factor V and X. What is the causative agent of her symptoms?

A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency room with severe shortness of breath, fever, and cough. The cough is productive with yellowish sputum and has been increasing for the past 2 days. He has been smoking for 25 years. He has been hospitalized twice for shortness of breath. He is taking a bronchodilator preparation twice a day. He denies chest pain or hemoptysis. His temperature is 100 F, pulse 94 beats/min, respiratory rate 25 breaths/minute, and blood pressure is 130/86 mmHg. Pulmonary function testing shows FEV1/FVC ratio to be <70% with no bronchodilator reversibility. FEV1 is <80%. A chest X-ray done 4 months ago shows a hyperinflated lung. What is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.option: Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

question: There is an overlap between chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases and their etiopathogenesis. Which of the following obstructive pulmonary disease involves the acinus?
Clinical signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolism mimic myocardial infarction. Which of the following is the most correct method of diagnosing pulmonary embolism?

A 75-year-old man is hospitalized for the past week with COVID pneumonia. He develops sudden-onset dyspnea and tachypnea. His lips appear blue and his oxygen saturation drops drastically. Chest X-ray shows bilateral diffuse infiltrates ("white lung"). What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 11-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a history of dry cough at night and early in the morning. She complains of her chest feeling tight and a whistling sound when she breathes out. Which of the following is true regarding this patient's condition?

answers.option: Most likely due to upper airway hyper-responsiveness to stimuli
Cough can be treated with cough supressants
Cough is due to chronic necrotizing infection of the bronchial walls
Airways will be dilated up to 4 times the normal size

question: A 30-year-old man suffers a head injury after a car accident. After a few days, he suddenly develops severe hypoxia, dyspnea, and goes into respiratory failure. What is a lung biopsy likely to show in this patient?

answers.option: Smooth muscle hyperplasia and excess mucous
Acute inflammatory cells in the alveoli
Epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells

question: A 30-year-old woman who has a history of rhinitis and nasal polyps presents to the clinic with complaints of repeated asthmatic attacks and urticaria. On further inquiry, she reports taking aspirin for her lower back pain. What is the most likely cause of her asthmatic attacks?

answers.option: Polyps in the nose predispose her to polypi in the lungs as well
Nasal polyps and rhinitis predispose her to necrotizing bronchial infections
Aspirin causes increased leukotriene production which causes bronchospam
Aspirin damages her distal airways causing them to dilate
She most likely has a positive family history for asthma

question: Which of the following subset of cells is involved in the pathogenesis of asthma?
Which of the following is inhibited by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)?
Which of the following best describes asthma?
Which of the following cells mediate allergic response in atopic asthma?
A benign tumor originating from glandular epithelium is termed as which of the following?
Caplan syndrome consists of which of the following?
A patient is admitted to the hospital with severe pleuritis. The amount of proteins in the pleural fluid is likely to be more than which of the following in this case?
A 65-year-old female is admitted to the ICU. She develops chest pain 3 days later. A chest X-ray is performed and reveals diffuse lung infiltrates. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 60-year-old female presents with complaints of difficulty in breathing particularly in the morning and during changes in position. She is coughing up a copious amount of mucus. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
A hospitalized patient suffers from respiratory distress and difficulty breathing. Chest x-ray reveals a white lung. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this case?
Which of the following stages of lobar pneumonia is characterized by the disintegration of erythrocytes and the presence of a grayish-brown exudate?
Which part of the lungs is primarily affected by bronchiectasis?

answers.option: Upper lobe of the left lung
Middle lobe of the right lung
Lower lobe of the right lung

question: Diffuse alveolar damage is the histological hallmark of which of the following respiratory conditions?
Which of the following is the least likely characteristic of asthma?

answers.option: Infiltration of eosinophils into the airways

question: Why do patients with emphysema often exhibit pursed-lip breathing?

answers.option: To increase airway pressure during expiration to reduce air trapping
To avoid chest discomfort during inspiration
To regulate filling of lungs that have increased compliance

question: Which of the following is the most common congenital disease affecting the lungs?

answers.option: Lack of pulmonary surfactant protein B

question: Which of the following statements is most appropriate about lung diseases?

answers.option: Restrictive lung diseases have partial obstruction at the level of bronchi
Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by reduced expiratory flow rate
Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by reduced expansion of lungs
Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by limitation to airflow
Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by limitation to airflow

question: Concerning community-acquired pneumonia which of the following statements is the most appropriate?

answers.option: The incidence is 5-11 cases per 10,000 population
The most frequently identified organisms are gram negative bacteria

question: A 75-year-old man, hospitalized for the past week with COVID-19 pneumonia, develops a sudden onset of tachypnea and dyspnea. His lips appear blue and his oxygen saturation drops drastically. Chest X-Ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates ("white lungs"). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 59-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with a complaint of frequent episodes of shortness of breath along with occasional cough with minimum sputum production for the last four years. He has been a known smoker for ten years. On chest auscultation, respiratory wheezes are heard. Chest X-Ray shows hyperinflation of both lungs. Pulmonary function tests show a decreased FEV₁/FVC ratio. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be a cause of these findings?
Which of the following is the most helpful and preferred method of establishing the diagnosis of asthma?
Which of the following congenital diseases affecting the lungs is most common?

answers.option: Lack of pulmonary surfactant protein B

question: Which of the following is the least characteristic of asthma?

answers.option: Infiltration of eosinophils in the airway

question: A 50-year-old man (a known patient with rhinitis and polyps) presents to your clinic with a history of repeated asthma attacks and urticaria. On further inquiry, she reports taking aspirin for her lower back pain. What is the most likely cause of her asthma attacks?

answers.option: Polyps in her nose also cause her to have polyps in her lungs
Nasal polyps and rhinitis predispose her to necrotizing bronchial infections
She most likely has a positive family history for asthma
Aspirin damages her distal airways causing them to dilate
Aspirin causes increased leukotrienes production which causes bronchospasm

question: Which of the following statement is correct about the lung diseases?

answers.option: Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by reduced expansion of the lung
Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by limitation to air flow
Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by reduced expiratory flow rate
Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by reduced expansion of the lung
Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by limitation to air flow

question: Which of the following is the most appropriate regarding community-acquired pneumonia?

answers.option: The most frequently identified organisms are gram-negative

question: A 75-year-old man has been hospitalized for the past 1 week with COVID-19 pneumonia. He develops sudden onset dyspnea and tachypnea. His lips appear blue and his oxygen saturation drops drastically. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates (white lung). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old healthcare worker, recently exposed to a patient with confirmed pulmonary tuberculosis, is concerned about possible infection. She undergoes a Mantoux tuberculin skin test. Two days later, the test site revealed a 12 mm induration. What mechanism best explains the positive result of the Mantoux test?

answers.option: Activation of B cells and antibody production against TB
Immediate hypersensitivity to purified protein derivative (PPD)
Direct activation of mycobacterial antigens in the skin
Activation of neutrophils and tissue destruction

question: Asthma is a common obstructive lung disease. It is characterized by which of the following pathological changes?

answers.option: Necrotizing inflammation and fibrosis of airway walls
Smooth muscle hyperplasia, excess mucus and inflammation
Airspace enlargement and wall destruction with no obvious fibrosis

question: A 22-year-old female presents with a persistent cough, low-grade fever, and unintentional weight loss of 5 for the past three months. She reports occasional night sweats and a family history of TB. On physical examination, lymph nodes are palpable and there are decreased breath sounds over the right upper lung field. A chest X-ray reveals a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe. A fine needle aspiration is performed on the lymph nodes and pus is aspirated. What is the underlying process behind this pus formation?

A 6-week-old infant presents with severe paroxysms of coughing and whooping sounds, along with posttussive emesis. The patient has not received any vaccinations yet. Bordetella pertussis infection is suspected and the patient is treated with antibiotics. Pertussis toxin, a known virulence factor of Bordetella Pertussis plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of the disease. What is the mechanism of action of this toxin?

answers.option: Inhibition of neutrophil chemotaxis to the site of infection
ADP-ribosylation of G proteins, leading to increased cAMP production
Inhibition of bacterial adhesion to respiratory epithelium
Blockade of histamine release from mast cells

question: A 35-year-old male presents with a persistent cough, low-grade fever, and night sweats for the past two months. He reports a history of working in a homeless shelter. Physical examination is unremarkable except for mild cervical lymphadenopathy. A chest X-ray shows infiltrates in the right upper lobe. Acid-fast staining of sputum confirms the presence of acid-fast bacilli. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the early events in the infection?

answers.option: Development of encapsulated cysts in lung parenchyma
Production of exotoxins causing tissue damage
Formation of abscesses in lung tissue

question: A 37-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with high fever, cough, and confusion. He is admitted to the hospital and a chest X-ray reveals multifocal, patchy consolidation. A diagnosis of atypical pneumonia is made. On probing, he provides a history of attending a meeting during the last week. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his illness?
In which of the following conditions is a barrel-shaped chest observed on examination?
A child has difficulty breathing upon inhalation of pet dander dust and smoke. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 12-month-old child presents with fever, cough, and increased respiratory effort. A chest X-ray reveals a right lower lobe consolidation with pleural effusion. Sputum culture grows gram-negative coccobacillary rods on chocolate agar. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old male, obese, smoker underwent surgery for a femur fracture. He stayed in the hospital for one week and was on anticoagulant therapy. At home, he suddenly developed dyspnea and cyanosis. He was taken to the hospital but could not survive. Which risk factor is least likely to be associated with his cause of death?

A 35-year-old male with a severe, persistent cough, and expectoration of foul-smelling sputum, particularly frequent when the patient rises in the morning. He also has a history of chronic sinusitis. On chest X-ray, bronchi are dilated, bronchovascular markings are increased, pulmonary vasculature appears ill-defined, representing fibrosis. What are the conditions that predispose to this disease?
Which one of the following is a feature of Kartagener syndrome?
What is a common trigger for acute asthma exacerbation?

Pulmonary surfactant is essential for life as it lines the alveoli to lower surface tension, thereby preventing atelectasis during breathing. Surfactant is enriched with a relatively unique phospholipid. What is this unique phospholipid termed as?

A 22-year-old male is brought to the emergency room with a complaint of being stabbed on the lower right side of the chest. An Xray of the chest shows a large collection of fluid in the lower right pleural space. Which of the following complications may arise?

A 30 year old male presents to the Emergency Room with sudden onset severe respiratory distress. He gives no history of trauma. On examination, he is afebrile, has a markedly increased respiratory rate and tachycardia. Breath sounds are decreased in the right upper part of the chest. Radiological imaging shows partly ruptured right sided peripheral apical subpleural blebs with collapse of the upper lobe of the right lung. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 63-year-old male presents to the Out Patients Department with consistently worsening respiratory distress for the past few weeks. He is in a senior management position in an advertising company. Radiological imaging shows markedly dilated air spaces in central parts of lung. What factor is most important in the etiology of this disease?

A 55-year-old male presents with worsening respiratory symptoms. He is a heavy smoker since the age of 20. Clinical and radiological examination confirms a diagnosis of emphysema. What is the hallmark of this disease?

A 65-year-old male presents with worsening respiratory symptoms. Clinical and radiological examination confirms a diagnosis of emphysema. What is the role of Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency in emphysema?

answers.option: It is a diagnostic criterion for emphysema
It has no role in emphysema
It increases strength of alveolar walls

question: A 69-year-old man who is a known patient of emphysema develops large subpleural blebs in his left lung. Some of them rupture and cause pneumothorax. Which type of pneumothorax is life-threatening due to increased intrathoracic pressure?
Which statement is correct regarding pathogenesis of cystic fibrosis as cause of bronchiectasis?

answers.option: It causes bronchiectasis through chronic lung infections and thick mu production
It primarily affects the cardiovascular system, leading to bronchiectasis
It is an autoimmune disorder that damages the airways, causing bronchiectasis
It leads to bronchiectasis by weakening the muscles involved in breathing
It is unrelated to bronchiectasis and does not contribute to airway damage

question: Which of the following histological findings is commonly associated with bronchiectasis?

answers.option: Chronic inflammation of the bronchial wall with destruction of the elastic and muscular components
Acute alveolar edema with neutrophilic infiltration of the alveoli
Complete regeneration of bronchial epithelium with preserved structure of bronchioles
Hypertrophy of the bronchial smooth muscle with absence of inflammation
Fibrosis and calcification of alveolar walls without bronchial involvement

question: Which of the following is most indicative of a clinical diagnosis of chronic bronchitis?

answers.option: Gradual onset of chronic cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath
Sudden onset of productive cough, fever, and purulent sputum, often associated with bacterial pneumonia
Persistent cough lasting more than 3 months for two consecutive years, often accompanied by dyspnea
Cough lasting more than 5 days, often preceded by an upper respiratory infection, with purulent sputum and absence of pneumonia
Hemoptysis and weight loss, with a history of smoking, suggesting possible malignancy

question: Which of the following is most suggestive of a clinical diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE)?

answers.option: Progressive dyspnea with orthopnea, peripheral edema, and elevated jugular venous pressure, typically seen in congestive heart failure
Sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea. tachypnea, and hemoptysis, often in a patient with risk factors such as recent surgery or immobility
Gradual onset of productive cough, fever, and crackles on auscultation, with a history of chronic lung disease
Chronic cough with wheezing, shortness ofbreath, and sputum production, commonly seen in patients with asthma or COPD
Pleuritic chest pain with a productive cough, fever, and dullness to percussion, indicating possible bacterial pneumonia

question: Which of the following is considered a major risk factor for the development of pulmonary embolism (PE)?

answers.option: Prolonged immobilization, recent surgery, or trauma
Chronic bronchitis and history of smoking
Long-term use of bronchodilators and corticosteroids
High levels of physical activity and regular exercise
Acute viral infections and recurrent sinusitis

question: A 30-year-old man has swollen, non-tender lymph nodes in the cervical region. He denies fever, night sweats, or weight loss. A biopsy of the lymph nodes reveals granulomatous inflammation. His Interferon Gamma Release Assay is positive. Which pathogen is most likely responsible for his condition?
Which of the following best describes Non atopic asthma?

answers.option: Asthma induced by aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), leading to severe respiratory reactions
Asthma triggered by physical exertion, often leading to shortness of breath and wheezing during or alter exercise
Asthma associated with exposure to specific allerg: ike pollen, dust mites, or pet dander, often accompanied by a history of atopy (allergic rhinitis or eczema)
Asthma caused by chronic smoking or exposure to occupational chemicals, often resulting in persistent symptoms and irreversible airway obstruction
Triggered by respiratory infections and events, such as exposure to cold and even exercise

question: Which of the following is a key mediator involved in the pathophysiology of asthma?

answers.option: Insulin: Regulates glucose levels and has no role in asthma pathophysiology
Histamine: Causes bronchoconstriction and increased mucus production during an allergic asthma response
Serotonin: Plays a major role in inhibiting airway inflammation and bronchoconstriction in asthma
Thyroxin: Directly responsible for triggering asthma symptoms by stimulating airway inflammation
Dopamine: Increases bronchial smooth muscle relaxation, preventing asthma attacks

question: A 35-year-old man who works as a fish tank cleaner presents with painful, ulcerating lesions on his hands and forearms. He reports sustaining abrasions while working. Which pathogen is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

A 35-year-old man presents with fever, dry cough, and confusion. He recently attended a business conference where several people reported similar symptoms. His chest X-ray reveals bilateral patchy infiltrates. Sputum Gram stain shows no organisms, beta urine antigen test is positive for a specific pathogen. Which organism is most likely causing his illness?
